title-group.subtitle: Percutaneous Fixation of Partial Incongruous Lisfranc Injuries in Athletes

contrib-group.aff: Foot and Ankle Reconstruction, Coordinated Health, Bethlehem, Pennsylvania

author-notes.corresp: Stephen A. Brigido, DPM, FACFAS, Department of Foot and Ankle, Coordinated Health, 2775 Schoenersville Road, Bethlehem, PA 18017; e-mail: drsbrigido@mac.com.

abstract.p: Open reduction with screw fixation is considered the standard surgical approach for injuries of the Lisfranc complex in athletes. However, multiple incisions are required, which increase the risk for postoperative complications. We present a novel percutaneous reduction and solid screw fixation technique that may be a viable option to address partial incongruous injuries of the Lisfranc complex in athletes. At our institution, no intraoperative or postoperative complications have been encountered. Screw breakage did not occur. Reduction of the second metatarsal was considered anatomic across all patients. All patients have returned to their respective sport without limitation. The percutaneous approach appears to decrease complications while the targeting-reduction guide appears to precisely reduce the injury. Consequently, outcomes have been more consistent and predictable. The authors note that this percutaneous approach is specific to partial incongruous injuries of the Lisfranc complex. When presented with more extensive injuries, the authors advocate an open approach.
Levels of Evidence: Expert Opinion, Level V

disp-quote.p: “Recent research indicates that a delay in surgical treatment [of Lisfranc injuries] is directly related to a compounded delay in return to athletic activity.”

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Although Lisfranc fracture dislocations account for less than 1% of all fractures in the general population,1-3 the incidence of midfoot sprains is dramatically higher for athletes.4 The injury is typically sustained when an athlete is subjected to an axial force with the foot plantar flexed and rotated,5 most commonly, resulting in a partial incongruent injury (Figure 1).4,6,7 When suspected, injury to the Lisfranc complex should be evaluated with comparison, weight bearing radiographs.6 Since computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging provide greater sensitivity, these studies can be used to further clarify or confirm radiographic findings. Computed tomography is recommended for high-energy injuries that require improved delineation of complex fractures.8 Alternatively, magnetic resonance imaging provides excellent depiction of ligamentous injuries and has been suggested as a means of evaluating return to play status in high-level athletes.9-11 Proper diagnosis and treatment are extremely important in preventing long-term disability.

caption.p: Full-thickness Lisfranc tear. Anteroposterior weight bearing radiograph showing partial incongruity of the second metatarsal due to lateral displacement and failure of the second tarsometararsal joint (type B2).

sec.p: Lisfranc injuries were originally classified by Quénu and Kuss in 1909.12 Modifications to the classification system were subsequently made by both Hardcastle et al (1982)1 and Myerson et al (1986).7 According to the amended classification system, the partial incongruous injuries most commonly seen in athletes are classified as type B.1,7,12 Following diagnosis, prompt surgical intervention is required for optimal functional results. Recent research indicates that a delay in surgical treatment is directly related to a compounded delay in return to athletic activity.13

The primary goal of surgical intervention is anatomical reduction. Since residual diastasis has been associated with significant pain and morbidity, the need to obtain anatomical reduction with rigid internal fixation has been emphasized throughout the literature.7,14,15 A number of studies have demonstrated that treatment with rigid internal fixation provides favorable, long-term results.2,14-16 Internal fixation has been performed with pins, plates, and cannulated screws, but screw fixation has demonstrated the most consistent results.2,14-19 Although the open reduction and internal fixation technique has been widely described in the literature, multiple incisions are required, which increase the risk for postoperative complications, such as skin necrosis, compartment syndrome, nerve entrapment, and delayed wound healing.16 Accordingly, when surgical intervention is indicated, percutaneous screw fixation is the advocated technique.9,20
We report a novel surgical technique for percutaneous reduction and solid screw fixation of partial incongruous Lisfranc injuries. To our knowledge, this technique is yet to be described.

sec.title: Surgical Technique
sec.p: The patient is placed on the operating room table in the supine position with an ankle tourniquet inflated to 250 mm Hg. Attention is directed to the medial cuneiform where a 1-cm incision is made over the central medial border. Under C-arm fluoroscopy, a stab incision is created over the proximal third of the medial cuneiform and on the lateral border of the second metatarsal. At this time, the radiolucent targeting guide (Figure 2) is placed in the incision (Wright Medical Technology, Arlington TN; Figure 3). C-arm fluoroscopy is used to confirm correct placement (Figure 4). External compression is placed on the guide, reducing the fracture or dislocation. Following reduction confirmation under fluoroscopy, a Kirschner wire is placed until the lateral aspect of the guide is encountered (Figure 5). The length of the screw is measured off the wire. A pilot hole is drilled through the targeting guide followed by drilling of the medial cuneiform. Either a 3.7 mm or a 4.3 mm solid screw is inserted (Figure 6). The targeting guide is removed. The incisions are closed using 1 or 2 horizontal mattress sutures with 4-0 Nylon. Patients should be placed in a posterior splint and advised to remain non–weight bearing for 3 weeks. Over the subsequent 3 weeks, patients are transitioned to weight bearing and CAM (controlled ankle movement) walking and then progress to physical therapy. A second procedure is required for screw removal. The hardware should be left in place as long as possible. At the earliest, screw removal should be performed at 4 months.

sec.title: Case Series
sec.p: The authors retrospectively reviewed the charts of 13 consecutive athletes (Table 1). The mean age at the time of operation was 21.9 years. The level of athletic activity and sport varied across the patient population (Table 1). All athletes included in this series were diagnosed with a type B2 fracture of the Lisfranc complex as defined by Quenu and Kuss–Hardcastle–Myerson classification system.1,7,13 All injuries were confirmed on weight bearing X-rays (Figure 7). If subtle changes were seen on the radiographs, a magnetic resonance image was obtained. After the risks and benefits were reviewed, the athletes elected to undergo percutaneous reduction using a radiolucent targeting guide and 3.7 mm or 4.3 mm solid screw design (Wright Medical, Memphis, TN). Patients were operated on by the principal investigator between February 2009 and August 2011. No complications were encountered intraoperatively. All patients were placed in a posterior splint and remained non–weight bearing for 3 weeks. A second procedure was required for screw removal. At the earliest, screw removal was performed at 4 months. The hardware remained in place as long as the patient could tolerate the discomfort.

caption.p: Patient demographics. Patient demographics are displayed for the athletes who elected to undergo percutaneous reduction and solid screw fixation of partial incongruous Lisfranc injuries (n = 13).
Preoperative radiograph. An anteroposterior weight bearing radiograph showing a partial incongruity injury of the Lisfranc complex (type B2).

sec.p: No postoperative complications were encountered in these series. Screw breakage did not occur. As evaluated by an independent physician, reduction of the second metatarsal was considered anatomic across all patients (Figures 8-10). On abduction stress radiographs, anatomic reduction was indicated when the medial column line intersected at the base of the first metatarsal without disruption15,21 and the medial border of the second metatarsal was in line with the medial border of the cuneiform. All patients returned to their respective sport without limitation. The average return to sport was 16.6 weeks. To date, no patients have presented with diastasis or loss of correction. The percutaneous approach with solid screw fixation maintained the correction in all patients.

Anteroposterior postoperative radiograph. If instability is noted within the intercuneiform joint, an additional fully threaded, solid screw can be inserted to restore anatomic alignment as demonstrated here.
Lateral postoperative radiograph. Screw placement is demonstrated from a lateral view.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The purpose of this study was to present a novel surgical technique to treat partial incongruous Lisfranc injuries in athletes. The technique used a percutaneous approach with solid screw fixation. A radiolucent targeting guide was used to determine correct placement of the screws and aid in reduction. In our initial series of 13 consecutive athletes, no complications were encountered, screw breakage did not occur, anatomic alignment was obtained, and all athletes resumed athletic activity in an average of 16.6 weeks. The percutaneous approach with solid screw fixation appears capable of attaining and maintaining the correction.

Even though conservative management has been advocated for treatment of midfoot disastases,4,6 operative treatment has been associated with a swifter return to sport for athletes.13 Investigators have reported the most consistent results with anatomical reduction and rigid internal fixation.2,13-16 Recent research indicates that either a percutaneous or open surgical approach can be used.20,22 However, open reduction is not without complication.16 Multiple incisions are required, increasing the risk for skin necrosis and delayed wound healing. Despite our small sample size, our initial results demonstrated no intraoperative or postoperative complications using the percutaneous approach. Presumably, the percutaneous approach effectively minimized soft-tissue dissection and damage and consequently, postoperative swelling and complications.

It has repeatedly been shown that rigid internal fixation of Lisfranc injuries results in more favorable long-term outcomes.15 Through the evolution of internal fixation devices, evidence has emerged to suggest that screw fixation are most successful technique for treating injuries to the Lisfranc complex.2,14-19 The primary concerns associated with transarticular screw fixation is postimplantation damage to the articular cartilage and screw breakage with subsequent hardware removal.19 Despite the risks associated with screw fixation, it remains the preferred fixation technique.9 In our study, internal fixation was achieved using solid screws. Promisingly, screw breakage did not occur. Our findings support the use of screw fixation to treat type B2 injuries of the Lisfranc complex.

Although open reduction has been considered the gold standard for Lisfranc repair in athletes, recent research indicates that the accuracy and maintenance of the reduction may be the strongest determinant of success.13,21 In our study, a targeting-reduction guide was used to determine screw placement and obtain reduction. According to previously defined parameters,15,20 proper anatomic alignment was achieved in all 13 patients. These results indicate that the targeting-reduction guide precisely reduced the injury. However, there are circumstances that may inhibit the effectiveness of this approach. For example, in the presence a fracture, the osteochondral fragments can impair the reduction. Therefore, we do not advocate this approach if the injury is not consistent with a type B2 injury or if adequate alignment cannot be achieved with the targeting guide.

In the literature, the average time to return to athletic activity has been described following nonoperative and operative treatment.5,6,13 However, nonoperative treatment strategies have been associated with inferior or failed outcomes.5 In the athletic population, prolonged pain and functional impairment have a resultant delay in return to athletic activity.13 Therefore, prompt surgical treatment has been advocated for athletes with diastases greater than 2 millimeters.13 In a retrospective cohort study, Nunley and Vertullo13 reviewed 15 athletes who were treated with open reduction and internal fixation of the Lisfranc complex. The average return to sport occurred in 14.4 weeks. Comparably, our return to sport averaged 16.6 weeks. Similar to Nunley and Vertullo,15 we recommend timely surgical intervention to treat type B2 injuries in athletes.

We presented a novel, percutaneous reduction and solid screw fixation technique that appears to successfully address partial incongruous injuries of the Lisfranc complex. Our findings indicate that the percutaneous approach provides a viable means of decreasing complications, and the targeting-reduction guide precisely reduces the injury. Consequently, outcomes have been consistent and predictable.
